## Introduction

The Elimisha (Sponsorship) program seeks to promote education among the under privileged (orphaned or in strenuous economic conditions) children in Kibera community. The program aims to educate, empower and engage the children for a sustainable future. Kibera currently has 117 children in the program, 60 girls and 57 boys, 51 Children are in Primary School, 55 in High School, 4 in University and 7 in College. We have 86 students in public schools and 31 in private schools.

## School Update

### Activities and Outputs

-   All the fee payments were paid within the first 3 weeks of schools opening.

-   64 families of the sponsored children were visited in the last six months at their homes.

-   Unfortunately, one of the sponsored children lost a parent due to illness. Spur Afrika shall support the child and family through this challenging time.

-   School/home visits

-   Tuition classes

-   Picnic/hike

![Niko the Sponsorship manager at the centre (in school uniform) catching up with some of the sponsored children](images/2023H2 Elimisha school visit.jpg){fig-align="center"}

### University/College Update

-   6 students are in University.

-   3 students are in colleges and 1 is set to join University in January 2024.

### Inputs and Resources

-   Spur Staff & Volunteers

-   Teachers

-   Mentors

-   Finances

### Outcomes and Impact

-   95% of the sponsored children attended school regularly.

    -   109 Students out of 117 students attended school throughout the school term. 2 students were absent due to sickness, 4 students missed school due to indiscipline cases. One was absent due to school transfer and one is scheduled to join college in 2024.

-   Increased school performance due to low absenteeism.

    -   Of the 117 students, 90 students performed above average and 25 students performed below average. One Student did not do the exams due to an indiscipline case.

-   Fourteen grade 8 students graduated to join high school.

-   Eleven form 4 students have successfully completed high school.

-   One student has graduated from the University.

## Mentorship Update and School Holiday Programs

### Activities and Outputs

-   All children were involved in 4 general group mentorship sessions with Spur Team Members. Discussion topics were: School progress, Mental Health, Relationships and Career choices.

-   65 sponsored children attending one-on-one mentorship sessions with their mentors.

    -   78 one-on-one mentorship sessions were held between July and December.

-   2 students had counselling sessions at the Spur centre.We had a picnic/football match with a partner organization. Spur Afrika football team won.

-   16 group mentorship sessions were held at the Spur centre with different groups of our sponsored children. Three Sessions for grade 4, 5 & 6, two session for grade 8, two session for grade 7, two sessions for girls only, three sessions for boys only and four sessions with all high school students.

    -   Discussion topics were, Self-esteem, how to pray, Personal hygiene, Resilience and relationships.

    -   Attendance of about 25 sponsored children in each session.

-   107 sponsored children attended a 6-day Spur Afrika, 'Unashamed' themed annual Camp in November. This is one of the most treasured activities amongst the sponsored children.

-   13 students who graduated from Primary school attended a 'Cross Over' mentorship program for 8 days in December. We met them for 8 days for 4 hours each day. Topics discussed were: effective communication, financial management, values, problem solving, time management, leadership and management.

-   50 Sponsored children attended an online career mentorship with Deloitte Australia.

-   20 Sponsored children attended coding classes for 3 weeks. 10 children attended Chess classes in November.

-   End-year camp

    -   110 children attended the end-year camp in Word of Life.

-   We had a picnic/football match with a partner organization. Spur Afrika football team won.

![High school students having a group discussion during our annual Camp, our theme for the camp was 'Unashamed'](images/2023H2 Elimisha unashamed.jpg){fig-align="center"}

#### Resources and inputs

-   Spur Staff & Volunteers

-   Finances

-   Mentors 

-   Counsellors

### Outcome and Impact

-   The is a change of behaviour e.g. *A* and *B*, who had previously had some cases of indiscipline.

-   Two of the students who had family and school challenges reported to be feeling better and understood after their counselling sessions.

-   General improved school performance, more children did well in their exams.

## Health Update

### Activities and Outputs

-   From July to December, 7 children got sick and received medical attention from the hospital. 

-   Reminded the children about oral hygiene education and gave them toothbrush and toothpaste.

#### Resources and inputs

-   2 Spur staff

-   NHIF (National Health Insurance Fund) and finances

-   Doctor's consultations and medication

-   End-of-year camp

### Outcome and impact

-   Sponsored Children were able to access better medical care.

-   Less number of children getting sick compared to the first half of the year. 

-   More children are brushing their teeth correctly leading to a decrease in dental problems.

## Challenges faced in the last six months

-   Some of the parents are still struggling to provide to their children school supplies and this may make the children miss school.

-   About 5 parents are not committed in helping their children with school work/picking report cards from school.

-   Family conflicts between parents (Gender Based Violence) and separation which affects the children negatively.

-   4 of the sponsored children had indiscipline cases at home/school.

-   25 children did not perform very well in their school work.

## Budget update

-   Funds used so far in the last 6 months is **Ksh. 3,040,864 (**approximately **AUD 30,400).**

    -   This includes cost of school fees, 6 day camp, Love box and cost of one full-time worker in charge of the program.

-   The funds allocated to the program were sufficient to cover the costs of the program.
